PIONEER Experiences

A word of explanation to the reader.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences or the same problems. Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone, but others may prove important to you. Remember so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If there is something to explain, or observe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer transportation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneer life in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child, etc.", etc.).
9. What were your reasons for coming West? TO TAKE UP A HOMESTEAD.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They approved.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Ship and Train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
I spent the first winter in a willow shack with Nathan Baker. We gathered willow branches from the banks of the South Saskatchewan River and packed them with clay to keep out the elements. About 1909 or 1910 when I filed for my homestead or 1909 when I filed for my pre-emption.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
McLean, near Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Matador, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
Vancouver, British Columbia.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
At school.
